DataElement.preferredName: Laboratory Procedure ALK Tyrosine Kinase Receptor Tumor Panel Sequencing Performed Tissue Biospecimen Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A description of the tissue biospecimen collected for tyrosine kinase receptor tumor sequencing.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Laboratory Procedure ALK Tyrosine Kinase Receptor Tumor Panel Sequencing Performed
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.:ALK tyrosine kinase receptor (1620 aa, ~176 kDa) is encoded by the human ALK gene. This protein is involved in ligand binding, tyrosine phosphorylation and signal transduction._An application of next-generation targeted sequencing where tumor-specific genes are selected for sequencing. Using next-generation techniques, chosen sequences can be sequenced to high depths that facilitate the identification of variants that are present at low allele frequencies._Executed and carried through to completion.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A procedure for critical evaluation; a means of determining the presence, quality, or truth of something.

Concepts.definition: Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.

Property.preferredName: ALK Tyrosine Kinase Receptor Tumor Panel Sequencing Performed
Property.preferredDefinition: ALK tyrosine kinase receptor (1620 aa, ~176 kDa) is encoded by the human ALK gene. This protein is involved in ligand binding, tyrosine phosphorylation and signal transduction._An application of next-generation targeted sequencing where tumor-specific genes are selected for sequencing. Using next-generation techniques, chosen sequences can be sequenced to high depths that facilitate the identification of variants that are present at low allele frequencies._Executed and carried through to completion.

Concepts.definition: ALK tyrosine kinase receptor (1620 aa, ~176 kDa) is encoded by the human ALK gene. This protein is involved in ligand binding, tyrosine phosphorylation and signal transduction.

An application of next-generation targeted sequencing where tumor-specific genes are selected for sequencing. Using next-generation techniques, chosen sequences can be sequenced to high depths that facilitate the identification of variants that are present at low allele frequencies.
Executed and carried through to completion.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position (locus) on a particular chromosome, is capable of reproducing itself exactly at each cell division, and directs the formation of a protein or other product. The gene as a functional unit consists of a discrete segment of a giant DNA molecule containing the purine (adenine and guanine) and pyrimidine (cytosine and thymine) bases in the ordered and correct sequence that encodes a specific functional product (i.e., a protein or RNA molecule).

DataElementConcept.origin: COG CRF:Children's Oncology Group Case Report Form

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The act of gathering something together._Any material sample taken from a biological entity for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes, including a sample obtained from a living organism or taken from the biological object after halting of all its life functions. Biospecimen can contain one or more components including but not limited to cellular molecules, cells, tissues, organs, body fluids, embryos, and body excretory products._Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A malignant tumor that has spread from its original (primary) site of growth to another site close to or distant from the primary site.

Concepts.definition: A malignant tumor that has spread from its original (primary) site of growth to another site close to or distant from the primary site.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A tumor at the original site of origin.

Concepts.definition: A tumor at the original site of origin.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: attributes of a patient's laboratory sample, including the source, condition, and fixative.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The act of gathering something together.:Any material sample taken from a biological entity for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes, including a sample obtained from a living organism or taken from the biological object after halting of all its life functions. Biospecimen can contain one or more components including but not limited to cellular molecules, cells, tissues, organs, body fluids, embryos, and body excretory products.:Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: The act of gathering things together; having been brought together in one place.

Any material sample taken from a biological entity for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes, including a sample obtained from a living organism or taken from the biological object after halting of all its life functions. Biospecimen can contain one or more components including but not limited to cellular molecules, cells, tissues, organs, body fluids, embryos, and body excretory products.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
